subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: ... Indeed we could, and we could get rid of They as well, as the rules for when to use it instead of Thaw are almost completely predictable (between vowels,
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I didn't want to bring this up earlier, but now seems the place for it.
> We could also get rid of either Wool or Ooze.

Indeed we could, and we could get rid of They as well, as the
rules for when to use it instead of Thaw are almost completely
predictable (between vowels, before TO final silent -e,
at the beginning in functions words the, then, they, them, those, etc.)

> Though I clearly distinguish between the two and would
> find it funny to hear "food" pronouced to rhyme with "good,"

Almost all accents have this distinction, except in Northern England.
I just saw today a nice mnemonic for the four main dialect groups of
England/Scotland, based on the pronunciation of "come down":

Scottish English: STRUT GOOSE
Northern English: GOOSE GOOSE
Midland English: GOOSE MOUTH
Southern English (and RP): STRUT MOUTH

> On the other hand, since Wool and Ooze cause no confusion (unlike On
> Awl, and Ah), we could just as well keep both Wool and Ooze.

I'd be in favor of that.

--
Yes, chili in the eye is bad, but so is your John Cowan
ear. However, I would suggest you wash your cowan@...
hands thoroughly before going to the toilet. http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--gadicath
